commander.name: Major-General Charles Keightley
commander.previous_service: Took command 19 May 1942, led division through Operation Torch, Kasserine Pass, and final Tunisia breakthrough May 1943

tanks.note: Division re-equipped with American M4A2 Sherman tanks March 1943 after Kasserine Pass losses. Sherman superiority over Crusader/Valentine evident in final Tunisia offensive May 1943.

Ordnance QF 25-pounder Gun-Howitzer.note: Three field regiments: 12th RHA (HAC), 152nd (Ayrshire Yeomanry) Field Regiment RA, plus one additional regiment

Ordnance QF 17-pounder (76.2mm).note: Limited allocation of new heavy AT guns for Tunisia campaign

Strong supply base from Algiers/Tunisia ports. Allied air superiority protects logistics. Fuel/ammunition adequate for breakthrough operations May 1943.

subordinate_units.note: Three tank regiments: 16th/5th Lancers, 17th/21st Lancers, 2nd Lothians and Border Horse. Re-equipped with Shermans after Kasserine Pass.
Motorised infantry brigade (replaced 38th Irish Brigade which transferred to 78th Division February 1943). Guards battalions provide elite infantry support for armoured operations.

tactical_doctrine.role: Armoured division - spearhead of British First Army final Tunisia offensive May 1943. Division blooded at Kasserine Pass (February), refitted with American Sherman tanks (March), designated spearhead of IX Corps breakthrough to Tunis (May). Captured Tunis 7 May 1943, accepted surrender of German 90th Light Division.
special_capabilities: American Sherman tanks (March 1943 refit) - superior to Crusader/Valentine
Combat-proven - Kasserine Pass, Tunisia campaign Nov 1942-May 1943
Elite Guards infantry brigade (replaced 38th Irish Feb 1943)
IX Corps spearhead - fresh corps for final offensive
Mobile combined arms - tanks, motorised infantry, SP artillery
tactical_innovations: Sherman tank superiority - 75mm gun, better armor than Crusader
Combined arms coordination perfected through Tunisia campaign
Capture of Tunis - first Allied entry into Axis capital
known_issues: Kasserine Pass losses (February 1943) - heavy casualties defending Thala
Sherman M4A2 diesel - less familiar to crews than British tanks
Transition from 38th Irish to Guards Brigade (February) - new unit integration
Infantry brigade insufficient for sustained operations (only one brigade for armoured division)
tactical_doctrine.combat_experience: Division first combat Operation Torch (November 1942). Fought 'Run for Tunis' Nov-Dec 1942. Heavy losses Kasserine Pass (February 1943) defending Thala. Refitted March 1943. Spearheaded IX Corps final offensive May 1943, captured Tunis 7 May, accepted surrender 90th Light Division. Division VETERAN by Q1 1943 end.

historical_context.formation: Formed May 1940 in UK. Trained for armoured warfare 1940-1942. Deployed Operation Torch (8 November 1942) landing at Bone/Algiers. First combat November 1942 Tunisia.
historical_context.kasserine_pass: Battle of Kasserine Pass (19-25 February 1943): Division (26th Armoured Brigade) rushed to defend Thala against Rommel's offensive. Heavy tank losses (Crusader/Valentine outclassed by German Panzer IV/Tiger). Successfully held Thala, preventing Axis breakthrough. 17th/21st Lancers suffered particularly heavy casualties.
historical_context.refit_march_1943: Division withdrawn from line after Kasserine. Refitted with American M4A2 Sherman tanks (March 1943). Sherman 75mm gun and armor superior to Crusader. Diesel engine (M4A2) unfamiliar but reliable. 38th (Irish) Brigade transferred to 78th Division (February), replaced by 1st Guards Brigade.
historical_context.final_offensive: IX Corps (Lieutenant-General Brian Horrocks) formed March 1943 as fresh formation for final offensive. 6th Armoured designated spearhead. Operation Vulcan (6-13 May 1943): Division broke through to Tunis, captured city 7 May 1943. Accepted surrender of German 90th Light Division. Participated in final Axis capitulation 13 May 1943 (250,000 prisoners).
historical_context.post_tunisia: Division served Italy 1943-1945. Fought at Salerno, Anzio, Gothic Line, Po Valley. Ended war Austria May 1945.
